titlestmt.titleproper: BU Records: Museum Studies Department, Inclusive: 1978-1997, undated, Bulk: 1990-1997

note.p: © 2021 The Texas Collection. All rights reserved.

profiledesc.creation: Finding Aid was generated by The Texas Collection staff, using the STAR Knowledge Center for Archives (SKCA) task that automatically creates EAD files from the Archive's SKCA catalog records.

did.head: Records Summary
did.unittitle: BU Records: Museum Studies Department
did.abstract: BU Records: Museum Studies Department contains a variety of materials from the museum studies department at Baylor University, primarily correspondence as well as administrative records.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: Baylor University's Museum Studies Department has been educating students in the field of museology since 1979. In that year, undergraduate courses were taught by employees of the Strecker Museum. By 1984, the program had received enough interest that the number of classes offered increased and the program expanded, allowing students to pursue either an undergraduate degree in Museum Studies. In 1993, Baylor officially recognized the museum studies program as an academic department. During that same year, the department launched its graduate degree program and offered students the option to pursue a Masters of Arts in Museum Studies with a concentration in administration. The program continues to operate today, offering courses to both undergraduates and graduate students but only granting master degrees.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: BU Records: Museum Studies Department consists of materials from 1978-1997 with some undated items. The records reflect the administrative and academic activities of the department, which was associated with the Strecker Museum. In particular, a large portion of collection contains materials from T. Lindsay Baker, who served as curator of the Governor Bill and Vera Daniel Historic Village, a departmental lecturer, and director of Academic Programs and Graduate Studies.

Series I. Correspondence contains letters that T. Lindsay Baker sent and received during the years of 1990 to 1997 as well as administrative correspondence from the Strecker Museum and Museum Studies Department. Series II. Administrative Records contains administrative records from the department such as student and employee information. Series III. Strecker Museum contains materials related specifically to the Strecker Museum and its relation to the department.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Prior to processing, this collection came organized in labeled folders with titles and date ranges. Some of the materials, such as the correspondence, were organized by month and year. The remaining materials were organized by subject and date. Most folder titles were retained during processing.
Currently, the collection is arranged in three series: I. Correspondence, II. Administrative Records, and III. Strecker Museum.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: All requests for copying of materials must be submitted to The Texas Collection in writing. Please use the Request Form for Copying Materials sheet. Unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator (s) of this collection are in the public domain. There are no restrictions on use. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

userestrict.head: Use/Re-use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: BU Records: Museum Studies, Accession #BU/355, Box #, Folder #, The Texas Collection, Baylor University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Described by Jackson Hager. Released on 2020-03-24.

relatedmaterial.head: Related references
relatedmaterial.bibref: “Museum studies major — first of its kind.” Baylor Lariat, 1978 October 31.
Cheung, Catherine. “Graduate school to offer new degrees”. Baylor Lariat, 1993 March 31.
Smith, Calvin B. Interview by Leslee Elliot & Becky Shulda. 2007 April 17 in Austin, Texas. Transcript. Baylor University Institute for Oral History, Waco, TX.

did.unittitle: Correspondence

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: This series contains correspondence from T. Lindsay Baker, who was the curator of the Gov. Bill and Vara Daniel Historic Village, a lecturer in the department, and director of Academic Programs and Graduate Studies. It also contains correspondence from the museum studies department and the Strecker Museum. The series is in excellent condition.

Administrative Records

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: This series contains the administrative files of the museum studies department which includes financial records, student and faculty records, and course information. The series is in excellent condition.

Strecker Museum

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: This series contains materials related to the Strecker Museum such as financial records, materials related to donors, and materials related to museum accreditation. The series is in excellent condition.
